newsitem.title: UK: UK group cites drinks which appealed to under-18s.
newsitem.headline: UK group cites drinks which appealed to under-18s.

text.p: Two alcoholic drinks, including a so-called alcopop and spirits packaged in plastic sachets that could be tucked into a pocket, violated British marketing guidelines by appealing to underage drinkers, a watchdog group said on Thursday.
The Portman Group said its Independent Complaints Panel is currently considering 34 other complaints, including four complaints referred to the panel by the Portman Group itself.

The Portman Group said the panel upheld complaints against Bliss, a fruit-flavoured alcoholic drink packaged in pink and purple and sold for 29 pence, and against Totpak, spirits such as brandy, tequila and vodka packaged in plastic sachets.
"The name 'Bliss and its packaging was considered likely to appeal to young girls, towards whom a magazine of the same name is targeted," the Portman Group said in its report.
Bliss is marketed by Utter Bliss Ltd.

The Portman Group also upheld complaints against Totpak, marketed by Pierhead Purchasing Ltd (Wines & Spirits), saying that "Totpak alcoholic sachets, containing neat spirits, were found to be unacceptable -- the portable, easy-to-hide packages being likely to appeal to under 18s."

The Portman Group said the products it has referred to the panel include Bullshit beer and Squeal, a fruit mix -- both of which were referred due to their potential appeal to those under age 18 -- and Scream'n Beaver beer and Kinky cider, referred due to their sexual connotations.
